column3: Automatic sanity-testing: PASSED, see http://jenkins.bluematt.me/pull-tester/da0fecffa788a0a74121d554d3d76936ab96b39e for binaries and test log.\nThis test script verifies pulls every time they are updated. It, however, dies sometimes and fails to test properly.  If you are waiting on a test, please check timestamps to verify that the test.log is moving at http://jenkins.bluematt.me/pull-tester/cu

ACK on code changes
(haven't tested memory usage, but looks like a good idea)
Currently trying a full sync...
I have a branch (serorphans) which is a merge of #3514 with this; it should provide some stronger memory usage guarantees, as it also limits the maximum number of orphans in memory.\n

My client appears to be stuck at block 202978 on the mainnet chain 
For some reason I'm receiving the entire chain starting from 0000000000000062e33609a6653b870f76f3f61e6f0aa3d9100ad12d78926a79 (#241041) to #241869 as ORPHAN BLOCK
Could of course be unrelated to this pull and simply a case of bad peers.

Oh... and it's already syncing again :)

(still lots and lots of orphans though, if you'

No, receiving orphans is very expected and one of the reason why I'm working on headers-first.\n\nThe problem is that any peer that announces some blocks, we ask for it, and if it's something whose parent we don't know, we ask for the parents - starting a pretty much full sync process from this peer, even if we were already syncing from another before. The problem is just that if you're syncing fr
Indeed. The amount of received orphans shouldn't be affected by these changes. So all the orphans are good for testing, in this case.\n

I did a succesful full sync with this patch.
The orphans picked up around #202978 were successfully written when it actually came to block #241041.
